summary: The memorandum from James B. Weidner to the file details an interview with John Stein on March 18, 1975, at CIA Headquarters, focusing on the Ad Hoc Committee's review of the CIA's alleged domestic activities, specifically the counter-intelligence (CI) staff's operations. The interview highlighted the CI staff's advisory role to the FBI, the benign nature of most of their activities, and specific projects like the American Targets Program (ATP) which indexed contacts between Americans and foreign intelligence officers. It also covered the handling of defectors and files on Americans, with mentions of the NOSENKO case and the Vesco file.
key_findings: The CI staff primarily served an advisory role, guiding the FBI on actions such as breaking and entering, without performing these actions themselves.
The American Targets Program (ATP) was a key initiative by the CI staff to document interactions between Americans and foreign intelligence officers, mainly from the USSR.
No evidence was found of the CI staff engaging in domestic physical or electronic surveillance; such activities were the responsibility of other agency components or the FBI.
The CIA's approach to defectors was utility-based, with the NOSENKO case cited as an example of defector rehabilitation.
Files on Americans were maintained by the CIA based on information from various sources, focusing on counter-intelligence implications.
